subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] On PALM
msgSnippet: ... I m not sure what you mean by here, if you mean just with Ado Roar, or with other vowels and Roar. But it so happens, by luck, that Read gave
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:

> > Anyway, I'm just trying to point out that the vowel before Roar
> > situation needs to be discussed a bit more. I see words appearing in the
> > news that still give me difficulty. Besides the example above, I come
> > across the Ed Roar combination for words in which I would use Age-Roar.
> > It takes me a while to figure out such words.
>
> As I've been saying, essentially no dialect makes a solid distinction here.

I'm not sure what you mean by "here," if you mean just with Ado Roar, or
with other vowels and Roar. But it so happens, by luck, that Read gave
prescriptions on how to spell many of these combinations. (I just came
across this a few days ago.)

merry Ed Roar (er)
Mary Age Roar (Er)
marry Ash Roar (Ar)
mire Ice Roar (Fr)
mar Ah Roar (yR)
more Awl Roar (Yr)
mere If Roar (ir)
murder Ado Roar (ar)

I got this from page 13 of the QS Manual.

These letter sequences have the following ligatures, in order: no
ligature, Air, no ligature, no ligature, Are, Or, Ear, Earth.

The sets these ligatures cover are DRESS + R, SQUARE, NEAR, PRICE + R,
START, NORTH/FORCE, NEAR, NURSE. At least, this is as far as I can tell.
I could be off here. I am noticing that If Roar and Age Roar are
distinct in the manual, but not distinct in lexical sets.

The problem I have with the news is that I see the Ed Roar combination
when I am expecting a If Roar or Age Roar.

Paul
